text.p: Zenith Electronics Corp. said Wednesday it is teaming up with affiliates of Oracle Corp. and Netscape Communications Corp. to launch new Internet television products.

Zenith, based in Glenview, Ill., said it plans to offer Internet television products -- set-top boxes and integrated television sets -- with interactive capabilities based on Network Computer Inc.'s System Software. Network Computer is a unit of Oracle.

In a separate statement issued at the Winter Consumer Electronics Show here, Zenith also said it plans to collaborate on consumer-based Internet software and services with Navio Communications Inc., the consumer affiliate of Netscape.
The products will allow TV viewers to access the World Wide Web, send and receive multimedia e-mail and participate in a variety of interactive and electronic commerce services.
Zenith said it plans to launch its "NetVision" Internet TV products this year, though the company was not specific.
The company said the set-top boxes and televisions will feature a printer port and smart card slot for home shopping, banking and other transactional services.
Zenith said its agreement with Oracle's Network Computer unit marks a new direction for its Internet televison product strategy.
"Working with Oracle, Zenith is redefining the experience of television and marrying channel surfing and net-surfing in a new exciting way," Peter Willmott, Zenith president, said in a statement.
James Barksdale, president of Netscape and a director of privately held Navio, said the Zenith alliance brings Netscape's Internet browser technology into the television market for the first time.
Zenith's stock was up $1.25 to $12.375 in early trading on the New York Stock Exchange while Oracle slipped 50 cents to $44.25 on the Nasdaq market.
